titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI:30. H. Humphreys here, for Methodist Church, Bridgport Connecticut. S. L Southard, upon Navy Department business. Attended the Drawing Room at the President’s— Crowd. Rebello and Oliveira— R. P. Letcher—called afterwards at the Office— Kentucky Legislature—projected Resolutions. Vote of the State in H.R.U.S. certain— Family party dined at our house. I dined at Williamson’s— Dinner given to La Fayette by the Members of Congress— P.U.S. attended. Speeches by him, by La Fayette, and by H. Clay— Clay’s opinions— Censure of the Administration. Military Spirit— Speech on Bolivar and South America. 16. Toasts, His proposal for a confidential conversation—accepted. Home at 9. Mrs Adams unwell— Suffering with influenza myself.

2. VII:15— Heard Lynde at the Capitol—late. Call on Garnett, who is ill. Met Calhoun’s there. Visit from G. Hay— A Stranger at Baker Matthew 3.10— A. H Tracy spent the Evening with me. Dr. Thornton—to go to South-America or Greece— Letter from M. Van Buren.

3. VII. I called at M. Van-Buren’s lodgings—out. A. H. Everett here— T. Randall, with a Letter from Mountain at the Havana, about Piracies— At the Office H. Forrest for G— Scott. English twice about his compensation and employment— Dickens about Genl. La Fayette and the Columbian Institute Dinner. Montoya with copies of the Mexican Constitution. Genl. Mason with Dias about an old claim of 1798 upon France. Poinsett, to invite me to dine with him to-morrow. Tuyll, for the paper he left with me, about the N.W. Coast Convention— Miller from Comee. Foreign Relations, to ask me to draw a Bill about Piracy. At P.U.S. Southard there. Consultation upon the Piracy Bill. Meeting for to-morrow. Despatch from H. Nelson— Wyer, about J. Scott— Evening past at T. B. Johnson’s— Mrs Adams came home unwell— Whist.

4. VI:30. W. Findlay here; Statesman Newspaper at Pittsburg to print the Laws— Remarks about Walsh— Morgan— Letters from W. H. Ireland, and J. Drake to P. Sharpe— Laws printing at N. York. Sharpe for the American— Cambreleng for Commercial Advertiser— Morgan for Noah’s
Advocate. Letter from M. Willett to Morgan— E. H Mills. Read to him the draft of Bill to suppress Piracy— W. Plumer jr with Low, who brought the New-Hampshire votes— Easter, about the House, he mortgaged; and his Deed— G. Hay, with the draft of P.U.S. Message, concerning his accounts and claims. Visit from P. Bentalou. Cabinet Meeting on the Piracy Bill— Discussion— Alterations— Fuller at the Office— A. Dickins, with Certificate of La Fayette’s admission as honorary member of Columbian Institute. Dined at Poinsett’s with La Fayette, Genl. Jackson &c. Evening party at Pleasonton’s. Mrs Adams confined to her chamber.

5. V:15. Mills came and took the draft of the Piracy bill— D. Trimble to recommend Harrison, as bearer of despatches— Credits on payment of duties to be abolished as to foreign merchants— N. Barber to introduce Captain Allen of the Cadmus— Reynolds of Tennessee about the printing of the Laws. At the office Lieutt Hunter of the Navy with an account against the Department of State— M’Ginnis with Pleasonton— O’Brien’s claim to go to Congress— Dias about his claim on France— Left a pamphlet. Quarles from Kentucky. D. Webster— Dined with the Columbian Institute at Williamson’s— About 30. Toasts. home before nine— At P.U.S— Southard there. Resolution calling for Correspondence from the Pacific— Stewart and Prevost, question whether it should be given— Meeting directed to-morrow.

6. V. W. Plumer here. Spoke of Conversations with D. Trimble— J. C Wright and S. Van Rensselaer— Also with P. Sharpe and J. W. Taylor G. Sullivan introduce C. H. Warren who applies to be Collector of New Bedford. D. P. Cook with Harrison an Elector, and bearer of the Electoral votes from Illinois— Trumbull, wants to go to Paris, to dispose of a picture of Raphael, and would be glad to be bearer of despatches. Niles of Baltimore— G. Hay—to say the President cannot find his Letters to Harris and the answer— Believes them to be at Loudoun. Hay offers to go— At the Office— Wyer, with the N.W. Coast Convention, and Advice and consent of Senate to ratify Cabinet Meeting. Resolution H.R— Call for South Sea papers— Not to be sent— I to see Ingham— Crawford, Calhoun, Southard present. Prevost’s Letters. He to be recalled. P.U.S. said he could not find his
Letter to Harris— Offered to give his own deposition— At the Office. J. W. Taylor and A. H Tracy about the printing of the Laws in Newspapers at New-York— I had appointed already the Advocate. Company to dine— Evening dancing party at T. Munroe’s.

7. VII. E. Wambersie, Consul at Rotterdam called— Wants a Salary. Visit to Van Buren, about Winne’s application for a consulate; and to Ingham, about the call for South Sea Correspondence— Miller of Pennsylvania introduced Newbold— Dr Kent came again with recommendation of W. G. D. Worthington for an appointment to South-America— James Barbour S.U.S. for Nelson’s despatch of 17. November, and recommendations for the Consular nominations— At the Office M’Ilvaine with Arnold from New-Jersey. Crowninshield, and Fuller— N.W. Coast Convention ratified; and prepared a draft of a Proclamation— Eve at home, writing—

8. VI:30. List of Visitors this day— At my house. J. Sloane of Ohio, with Mr Green, and Mr Christians from that State. Saml. Bell, Senator from New Hampshire, and Samuel Dana of Massachusetts. T. Newton, M.H.R. with a Mr Williamson from Norfolk, Virginia, Saml. Eddy M.H.R. from Rhode-Island with a Mr Easton from Newport. Moses Hayden M.H.R. from the State of New-York. Saml Harrison Smith with two brothers named Kirkpatrick, and another person from New-Jersey— At the Office. J. L. Sullivan with Judge Wright, civil Engineer of Erie Canal. Mr White, also civil Engineer employed on Union in Pennsylvania. Dr. Howard of the Board of internal improvement. Son of Coll. Howard of Baltimore. Lieutt. Mayo of the Navy twice, about his claim for bringing despatches. Henry Wilson M.H.R. from Pennsylvania, to plead for M’Ginnis upon the O’Brien claim. J. T. Sandford. M.H.R. from Tennessee, for a claim of Gilchrist an assistant of the Marshal of that State in taking the late census and account of manufactures. J. Bailey M.H.R. from Massachusetts and Baron Tuyll, to confer upon the exchange of the Ratifications of the N.W. Coast Convention. We agreed to make it next Tuesday at one. I dined at P.U.S. with a company of members of Congress and attended an Evening Ball at Genl. Brown’s, given to Genl. Jackson, in honor of the day.

9. VI:30 Note from H. Clay. Heard Little. from Ecclesiastes 7.23—and Mason at Baker’s from Hebrews 11.1. Between services called on J. W. Taylor and A. H. Tracy— Letter from Tallmadge. H. Clay passed the Evening with me. Long Conversation. Explanations of Ghent transaction— Views of the west— His own views— Mr. and Mrs Everett, and Genl. Wingate, above— Johnson Hellen returned yesterday to Rockville— Alternatives in my contemplation—

10. VI:45. Visits at my house from John Herkimer and Parmenio Adams Members H.R. from New-York, with a Mr Ketchum, and with enquiries, Herkimer about a German Estate for a man named Meyer, and Adams for his brother Dan lost at Queenstown in the late War— T. W. Cobb. S.U.S. from Georgia, wishing to transmit a Letter to France— E. Selden, concerning papers for the Slave-indemnity Commission. D. White M.H.R. from Kentucky, to recommend again a Mr Edmiston, as a Secretary of Legation in South America. Coll Mosher the President’s private Secretary, with his Message to H.R. declining to send the South Sea papers. Mr Dexter a nephew of the late Samuel Dexter of Boston— At the Office. Jer. Nelson M.H.R. from Massachusetts with a Mr Wheelwright— Hodgson, to whom papers were given for translation— A young man named Cochran applying again for a Clerkship in the Department, with recommendations. Mr Dunlop of Georgetown, brought a Commission from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, for taking my deposition (the fourth) in the case of Levett Harris vs. W. D. Lewis. D. Strobel, the Consul at Bordeaux, to give explanation upon a complaint of a Captain Meyer against him— Lieutt. Mayo for his charge against the Department of State for bringing despatches from Commodore Stewart—disallowed— Baron Tuyll, with copy of the N.W. Coast Convention, and the draft of Certificate of Exchange of Ratification, in French, prepared for sealing and signature— Coll. F. Johnson, M.H.R. Kentucky, with a Mr Jones from that State, and lastly E. Wyer I called at P.U.S. and left with him the papers relating to the quarrel between R. Rush and J. A. Smith— Also H. Nelson’s last despatch & enclosures, and two Notes from Baron de Mareuil the French Minister. Spoke of a Letter from L. Harris to C. J. Ingersoll
transmitted by him to P.U.S. mentioned in this new Commission, but which I had never seen— He did not recollect it. Evening at a party at R. Smiths. Cashier U.S. Branch Bank. G. Hay there told me that P.U.S. had found the Letter from Harris to Ingersoll— And that he had never communicated it to me before, on account of its impertinence.

11. VII. Visitors, W. Plumer jr. Settled with him for his payments on acct. of T. J. Hellen— Electioneering talk. G. Johnson—endorser upon paper of Ladd of Alexandria, who has failed, to the amount of 7800 dollars—but hopes not to be made responsible for them— Bad condition of grain and flour trade— To wind up the concern. G. Hay brought me a Letter from L. Harris to P.U.S. of 10. Feby. 1823 a Letter from Harris to C. J. Ingersoll dated 19. Feby 1823. and a Letter from C.J. Ingersoll to P.U.S. enclosing it and dated 24. Feby. 1823— While Mr Hay was with me, I received a note from D. Brent stating that P.U.S. had sent for me to attend a Cabinet Meeting. I went immediately to the Office, and exchanged with Baron Tuyll the ratifications of the N.W. Coast Convention— Baron Maltitz was with him, and read the original Treaty— I held the Russian ratified copy— Baron Tuyll ours, and Mr Ironside the copy received from Baron Tuyll by his Government. We executed in French and English two Certificates of the Exchange— Lieutt. Turner came about his account, which was allowed. I. Wayne M.H.R. from Pennsylvania with a Mr Kimber who left with me papers concerning a patent claim. J. Scott M.H.R. from Missouri, about the appointment of a Governor of Arkansas. He will call upon me again— I attended the Cabinet Meeting at P.U.S— Calhoun and Southard present. Crawford had been, but was gone. Negotiation with Creek Indians— Report of the Commissioners— Letter from D. G— M’to the Secretary of War. The papers given to me to read— P.U.S. told me he had never communicated to me L. Harris’s Letter to C. J. Ingersoll, on account of its rudeness and incivility. And that Harris’s conduct was extremely reprehensible in retaining the papers. He shewed me also two other Letters, from Harris to him, which I had never seen before.
One of 5. Octr. 1819. soliciting the appointment of Minister to Russia; and one of 22. Decr. 1822. complimentary, upon the annual message of which the President had sent him a printed copy— After my return to the office, J. Rowlett came with an Atlas for sale, which I did not buy, and J. Bailey who gave me a minute of the anti-caucus meetings in January 1824— Mrs Adams had her third alternate Tuesday Evening party. 8. Senators 59 members of the house and about 150. others attended. I introduced P. Adams to Mr Addington— Genl. La Fayette was here.

12. V:30.Thomas J. Hellen went at 6. in the Stage for Baltimore, returning to the Academy at Exeter New-Hampshire. M. Van Buren S.U.S. called to make enquiries concerning A. B. Woodward nominated as judge for the middle District of Florida— While he was here, Mr Calhoun came for the papers relating to the negotiation with the Creek Indians, which I had read, and now returned to him— G. E. Ironside came concerning some documents erroneously transmitted from the President to the Senate, instead of being sent to the Printers— Walter Forward M.H.R. from Pennsylvania came and introduced a Mr Eickborn from Pittsburg— W. C. Bradley M.H.R. from Vermont, came upon a claim of C. P. Van Ness now Governor of that State; late Commissioner under the 5th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent. he spoke also of the approaching election— Of Mr Chase, the Senator chosen for the next Congress from Vermont— And asked if there would be a special Call of the Senate on the 4th. of March. He mentioned likewise the recent Message of P.U.S. to Congress, upon his claims and Accounts— Bradley, with the misfortune of deafness is one of the most intelligent members of Congress. At the Office W. Burleigh of Maine M.H.R. came and spoke of charges against M. L. Hill Collector of Bath, which the delegation from the State wished to have investigated. He also recommended a young man for employment in a public Office. At P.U.S. he said he should, as he had done in similar cases refer the case of M. L. Hill to the Attorney General. Some Conversation upon the appointment to be made of C. Hughes jr. as Chargé d’Affaires at Copenhagen. I asked whether L. Harris had ever made him a special communication concerning me, as asserted in his Letter to C. J. Ingersoll.
He said not to his recollection, and repeated that the conduct of Harris in retaining the papers was extremely reprehensible. I dined with Messrs. Van Buren, Van Rensselaer and M’Lane. and took with me the papers that had been requested by Mr Van Buren. Genl. La Fayette, Genl. Jackson, Mr Clay, Mr Calhoun and Genl. S. Smith were there— I attended at the Drawing-room, with Mrs Adams and Elizabeth— James Lloyd of Massachusetts spoke of the printing of the documents relating to R. Rush’s late Negotiation in England. James Barbour and R. King had spoken of it last Evening. The President said he saw no objection, to their being confidentially printed for the use of the Senate. I suggested to Mr Barbour that the papers should be returned to the Department by the Committee, and then called for by a Resolution of Senate sitting on Executive business.

13. VI:15. I called this morning on James Barbour S.U.S. and asked him to return the long report of R. Rush’s Negotiation, and then move a call for it, and for the Instructions, under which the negotiation was conducted, in Senate, upon Executive business. He agreed to take this course. I spoke to him confidentially with regard to the approaching election; and told him the present condition of things, at which he appeared surprized. He repeated the unalterable determination of Virginia to vote in the first instance for Mr Crawford, but her determination at all Events to vote for another than a mere military leader— Returning home, I met Mr R. King, who spoke of a proposition of J. S. Johnston to apply all the proceeds of Land sales to purposes of Education— He King thought of proposing that they should be applied to the emancipation and exportation of Slaves, with the consent of the Slave States. He said they would all consent, North of South-Carolina. After I came home J. J. Stull Cashier of the Farmers and Mechanics Bank, at Georgetown, came to apprize me of G. Johnson’s having endorsed Ladd’s Notes to the Amount of 7000 dollars, and enquiring if I was not responsible for Johnson. I told him no—I had never authorized G. Johnson to endorse any note, but had enjoined him always not to do so— I sent my son John to take possession of all the Stock at the Mill, and the warehouse, which
he did. Mr Vernon paid me a visit, and A. Livermore M.H.R. from New-Hampshire, came to enquire how it happened that D. Humphreys had been reappointed U.S. District Attorney, in that State, during the last Session of Congress; his former Commission as Livermore supposed having not expired till after the commencement of the present Session— I found on enquiry at the Office that the new Commission of D. Humphreys commenced on the 22d. of November last— Genl. Wingate came to enquire for an answer to the petition of a man named Timmins for a remission of a penalty. He spoke also of the charges against M. L. Hill, and in case of his removal recommended a person named Swanton— At the President’s. He found the petition of Timmins, and a minute of Mr Hay’s, upon it. I asked him if there would be a call of the Senate on the 4th. of March which he said must be considered— I spoke to him in Confidence concerning the election, and said that whatever might be its result I should wish for his friendly Counsel after the event, and as far as he might be disposed to give it, before. I told him my present intention was in the event of Genl. Jackson’s election, to retire. He spoke cautiously, but expressed a willingness to advise me so far as might be proper— He said he had at the eve of his first election been much beset—by none more than Jonathan Russell— Hinted at Mr Clay’s resentments— At the uses made of his Letter to Genl. Jackson, which he again declared he firmly believed he had never shewn to any one. He spoke also of Forsyth, with moderation; but with a sense of injury. He read me his message upon Piracy, this day sent in. After my return to the Office, I had visits from J. Reed of Masstts and Genl. M’Arthur of Ohio, members H.R. We had company to dine 4 Senators 16. members of H.R. and 2. others.

14 V. A rainy day: consequently not much interrupted by visitors; At the Office F. Baylies, M.H.R. from Massachusetts, came with vouchers of a claim for a man named Coggeshall for travelling as an Express, from New Bedford to New York, with a despatch from T. Lear in January and February 1808— After much objection to the charges, as excessive (amounting to 212.81. dollars) I took the vouchers for examination at the Treasury Department, and shall
then see Mr Baylies concerning them again— Immediately after dinner T. Dunlop of Georgetown, and Mr Coxe of the same place came to my house, and proposed to take my deposition, (the fourth) in the case of L. Harris vs W. D. Lewis— I had told Dunlop that I should object to Genl. J. P. Van Ness’s acting as a Commissioner— Dunlop now said that he had before I suggested that objection given notice to Genl. van Ness of the Commission, and he had said he would attend— He had since informed Genl. Van Ness of my objection, and now proposed that the deposition should be taken at Williamson’s Hotel— I had already said that I withdrew altogether my objection to Van Ness, and now said I was entirely willing that he should come and join in taking my deposition at my own house— They went to Williamson’s, and at seven O’Clock returned with Coll. Ashton— Dunlop said that Genl. Van Ness declined coming to my house— Mr Cambreleng is one of the Commissioners for the Deft. Lewis, but did not attend. Coxe and Ashton were the Commissioners for Harris— Dunlop for Lewis— From seven till ten, they were taking my answers to the interrogatories on the part of the Deft. Lewis, and then adjourned to meet again at my house at 6. O’Clock next Monday Evening— [symbols] for my hoarseness and cough.
